pros: Very flexible - not your typical 9 to 5 job; rewarding work - spent time working on Covid-19 Project; not stuck in an architecture that no one believes in. Benefits are excellent.
cons: Long hours and stressful. Because requirements gathering is on you, as the Business Analyst, many projects start off as a blank screen, with the question, "what do you want?" often followed with "I don't know". This isn't an IT shop where there are BAs and Product Managers writing up a feature document to hand to the dev team. In many ways, you the Software Architect, will wear every hat imaginable and at many times wearing multiple hats at the same time. You will learn a ton but not without consequences. If you can manage expectations, keep your work hours down below 60 a week, this is a great job.

pros: University benefits are great, and if you last past your 6 month probationary period you also get an education benefit as well.
cons: Institutionally none that I can think of at this time. Within my department yes: there is a lot of passive aggressiveness within the histology laboratory disguised with southern hospitality. One tech is definitely rascist, she will definitely pick on you if you are black or Latino. There is also a buddy system within the laboratory. The manager prides herself on making a team that works together and is full of team players, but the truth is that they were all there at least 6-12 years ago, and it's actually very skeptical of new hires coming in; many of them are not team players, one female histotech has cussed out a pathologist and walked out on her shift but is still working there.

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Birmingham, AL

job_title: Acute Care Nurse Practitioner in Birmingham, AL
pros: Excellent Hospital and excellent work environment

job_title: Director, Ambulatory Services in Birmingham, AL

job_title: Lead Patient Care Coordinator in Birmingham, AL
pros: Great benefits and good opportunities
cons: Being in alabama. Parking is not great.

review_title: UAB - A Reason to be called The Best.
pros:
1. Staff
2. Patients
3. Opportunities
4. Research Hospital 
5. Great Benefits
6. Prestige
7. Resources
8. Education advancement paid for you and family
9. MAGNET Hospital
10. Great retirement offered.
11. CEU's offered all the time
12. Old ICU is now a MOCK Simulation floor to increase knowledge, free practice basically.
13. Lots of doctors and residents. :)

I generally love this hospital because it has so many great benefits.  It is nestled in the heart of Birmingham, has 7 ICUs and upwards of 40+ segemented floors.  We are also adding a Women and Children's unit in 2009 that will eventually connect with Birmingham Children's Hospital via crosswalk/crossover.  How awesome!
cons:
There isn't a great transit system set up for this city.  Parking is limited (free), whereas I pay $6/day to park closer, in a deck :/  I am a new graduate and have been there for five months.  They offered us parking 9 blocks away for $50/month.  There are some closer decks but have mostly been taken.  

Birmingham City Tax is also taken out, along with State and County etc.  
Also, Alabama Teacher's Credit union is a mandatory five percent removal from your check to set aside in a savings account for you.  It can be accessed with a twenty percent penalty or rolled over into stocks.

review_title: Far From a Good Place to Work for
pros: Job culture was laid back, Friendly employees at my employment level
cons:
Getting to the downfalls of working for UAB...If you're an entry-level IT technician looking to gain experience and knowledge in the field, then I would advise anyone to not apply to this place since senior HSIS management will not appreciate any work that you do or even appreciate the "little guy" who has been going the extra mile for them when they don't ask you to. 

Also, it's been noticeable that management shows a lot of favoritism to their so-called star technicians and ignores those that are on an equal playing field doing the same kind of work as the star technicians. There have also been some cases where HSIS will terminate you without warning or notice even if you do nothing wrong. 

Besides these major cons, the pay is horrible for a level 1 technician as well as the fact that you would have to pay for parking which can take a bite out of your paycheck after each week.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros:
Schooling opportunities 
Benefits
Discounts
Some better opportunities
cons:
Work long hours 
Not enough pay
Unmanageable
Always short staffed

job_title: RN At UAB in Birmingham, AL
pros: I had a great experience at UAB. It is a magnet hospital, so I felt like things were automatically done the right way. Plenty of residents and doctors nearby willing and ready to help. All the supplies and technology are at hand so that you can readily and easily take care of your patient. The last unit I worked on came by and asked me every month what was working and not working for me and any people I would like to recognize. I thought that was great. There are also many departments within UAB for a wide variety of job choices. Lower pay than some hospitals.
cons: Parking is expensive. Sometimes they require you to be on committees, etc which is hard for people like me who simply want to work hard and go home. I felt pressured to be involved as if there were consequences if I didn't.

review_title: Only worth it if you want to continue education
pros: *Almost* all of your tuition is covered if you want to continue schooling at UAB after you've been a full-time employee for 6 months.
cons:
You have to pay a minimum of $50/month to park in a deck, or risk paying $6/day in the overflow deck (that's always full before 8AM) or parking in the street where you have to feed your meter regularly. 
Health insurance provided to employees seems great until you actually need to have a medical procedure or anything more than a regular check-up. Monthly cost that is removed from paycheck is much, much higher than competing medical programs.
Unless you are a physician, pay rates are not at all competitive or negotiable, and upward movement/raises/promotions are hard to come by.

pros: Access to educational opportunities including educational benefits to pursue a college education or advanced education for self and/or family, autonomy for those who do their jobs effectively
cons: Ungrateful millennials who complain and gossip more than they work, unprofessional staff who give the Department a bad name, negative people who keep the morale low with lies, lack of accountability and fairness; pay for MSW is significantly less than that of a RN case manager even those who only have a BSN, Director shows favoritism

review_title: UAB endeavors to take care of their employees.
job_title: PATIENT ENCOUNTER SPECIALIST in Birmingham, AL
pros: UAB offers a great environment to work in. I worked at the Kirklin Clinic specifically. Everyone worked together and was always looking for a better way to communicate with each other. The insurance options are great as well as the tuition reimbursement program. They really encourage their employees to always work to better their education. There were free training classes offered to employees as well. Along the employee health and wellness program that included free yoga classes and 12 free mental health visits a year.
cons: Parking is an ordeal. Most places offer commuter lots and a (fast) bus system to take you to work, some other departments have parking decks where you can get a monthly pass for a discounted rate.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Port Birmingham, AL
pros: Stable large employer with great culture and values, Birmingham is fortunate to have UAB in town. It is not easy these days to predict your job future in 3-5 years but at UAB Medicine most of the folks have very stable jobs unless do something really stupid. Love my job
cons: Parking issues for sure, remote lots are too far away. UAB runs buses and those lots are like $14/month, but they add a lot of time and frustration. Restrooms have very short walls, you can see each other. But hey, it is a hospital

review_title: When you do your job right, you get to do someone else's job too
pros: Great benefits, opportunity to build great relationships with your co-workers
cons: Management only cares about money coming in, they don't really show that they care about their employees. A lot of them are two faced and only nice on the outside. Too much gossip, both from co-workers and management. Parking is a nightmare and costs too much.

review_title: Excellent experience; great leadership and vision.
pros: Organization is highly committed to quality care for patients. There was a learning environment for all levels of employees - clinical, administrative, and trainees. Senior leadership always had an open door for mentoring, innovative ideas, etc. Overall, i experienced what i would describe as an ideal blend and degree of engagement from the clinical and administrative leadership. Great place to work, grow a career and made a difference in people's lives.
cons: No cons; I had an excellent experience. It's a job that I would go back to. I was a vital and valued part of a team of leaders on all levels who were extremely engaged and sincerely interested in doing what's best for the patient and organization.

review_title: Messy Coworkers , Unfit Management , Decent Pay
job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Pay ,Tuition Benefits , Benefits
cons: Management can be rude , and racist ! A lot of micromanaging , and favoritism! UAB could be a great working environment if the management was better! Parking also can be a hassle.

pros: Large teaching hospital with opportunity for advancement.  Excellent benefits, very affordable insurance and Magnet certification means better working conditions for nursing.  Lots of autonomy and excellent environment for learning.  General nurse patient ratio is 1:2 in the ICU, 1:5 on the floor.
cons: Pay is lower than other local hospitals.  No student loan payback program or sign on bonuses.  Parking is a problem, must park on the street (which can be dangerous) or pay at least $50 a month for a deck that could be a couple blocks away.

pros: Within the southeastern United States, UAB is unparalleled in most subfields of biomedical research. Senior faculty are genuinely motivated to get junior faculty and postdocs involved. Postdoctoral programs at UAB are consistently ranked among the best in the nation. By working in the southeast, it is easy to get your "boots on the ground" because you are serving a population with an enormous health disparity.
cons: As with any large university, there are gaps in accountability. This translates to a work environment where slackers can slide by without being exposed. If you are sensitive to this type of inequality, you must either speak up or learn to ignore it.

review_title: Has great potential, but not quite there
job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Amazing benefits, relaxed culture, the highest level of management is great.
cons: UAB HSIS overall is a joke. The employees that are desktop support tech II are the least qualified to be in a higher position. Additionally, work flow is distributed poorly and often unfairly.

review_title: Good place to work, but has it's problems too.
pros:
The salary is competitive compared to working on an ambulance. 
Your coworkers are an extension of your family.
cons: Management held onto positions instead of hiring new nurses because they got a bonus for staying under budget leading to short staffing.  Things appear to be changing direction now with new management, but I'm still leaving.

review_title: ER RT at UAB "Employee of the Month"
pros: A level 1 trauma center on the bleeding edge of Medicine. A true grind house for the newly minted doctors, nurses, and other healthcare staff. You will never see this level trauma or learn more about healthcare anywhere else.  Hard work is recognized as well as your level of expertise. tight nit crews who are open and inviting.
cons: Management who is out of the loop; popping in to excerpt their authority without a complete grasp of the situation.

review_title: Great company if you have benefits
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Reputable organization, good organizational culture, employee recognition (verbal praise/small tokens of appreciation)
cons:
If you are in a lower level position, raises are minimal. Your best bet for growth is to just apply for another position entirely.

Was told during the interview process that I would be benefitted; after being hired it became a "maybe". In the end it never happened.

pros: UAB is a great hospital and highly respected. My experience here is undeniably irreplaceable. Lots of opportunity to become involved with the politics of the hospital. Several nursing programs within the hospital such as the Nursing Congress, Professional Nursing Development Program and BSN Residency Program. The ability to sign up to work on different units through self scheduling. Scheduling is very flexible. Tuition reimbursement!
cons: UAB requires nurses to have BSNs which is a good thing but they dont pay well enough. They should at least pay the difference in comparison to ADNs.  Parking is the pits!

pros:
-I am PRN
-Work on ALL floors of the hospital, with a variety of patients and co-workers
-Overtime almost always available
-UAB's new minimum wage
cons:
-LOW autonomy
-You are not authorized to do anything but assist the tech or nurse, but this is great if you want to use some time to study for school
-Can be cancelled or sent home if patient no longer needs a sitter
-Certain patients can really strain you mentally...you have to sit in a room with them for 8 to 12 hours, can not leave them alone without someone coming to relieve you...

job_title: PATIENT ENCOUNTER SPECIALIST in Birmingham, AL
pros: UAB has great benefits and incredibly motivated workers. I loved talking to people in different departments that enjoyed their job.  Mostly security and patient services.  Wonderful people! Also the ladies at Starbucks, so nice and friendly.
cons: Lack of communication. Two different managers, plus doctors, plus the hierarchy within my department meant there was a lack of communication. The manager I mostly worked with had no empathy for my job because she had never done it. When you work with the general public in health care, not all patients that you meet will be kind. Most are in a bad mood and it is your job to make sure they are as comfortable as possible. Every patient that came to my desk was met with a smile and 100% customer service. However, my manager was not interested in the success stories. The only time she interacted with me was to reprimand me on a situation I usually had little control over. For example, I once had a patient come up to me to ask a question. If you have worked in a clinic setting this happens a lot and mostly when you are with another patient or completing a different task. This patient in particular already had hostile body language.  I kindly told her I was on the phone, looking back I would have clarified that I was with a patient. The patient then went to complain about the rude girl who was taking a personal call and refused to help her. My manager overheard and marched (powered walked) to me and began to accuse me of being rude to a patient. This was the third instance in which her passion for reprimand overthrew her ability to understand a situation.  She was passionate about me not doing my job correctly and being rude to customers and I quote "You need to be nicer to patients". Usually, I am always open to criticism but her reaction was so unfounded I almost cried on the spot from frustration.  More often than not I had rude patients that I had to smile at and pretend not to notice their horrible behavior. My fellow coworkers would compliment me on how much I cared and listened to our patients and to have my manager tell me I needed to be nicer made me realize that she never noticed my work. She didn't see how hard I tried and how many people I made smile. That was when I knew I was done. The job gave me much anxiety over miscommunication within the office.

review_title: Coworkers like Family, Department like Home
pros: Almost everyone in the department works as a team. [Most of]Your coworkers and supervisors have your back at all times. The physicians are courteous and respectful of your opinion and your time. It truly felt like you were part of one big family. Plus, the benefits were about as good and affordable as you can get in this area.
cons: The hours of operation  are quite strenuous for an employee with a family and obligations outside of work.

review_title: Great place to work with great people
pros: UAB Hospital is a wonderful place to work with very knowledgeable staff. It is also a designated "magnet" hospital which means they achieved excellence in nursing care and were able to meet the qualifications for that title. If I were to become really sick, there is no other place I would rather go!
cons: There really aren't any cons. It's located in the heart of downtown, so you have to be careful when walking around. Be aware of your surroundings.

pros: There are some very good people working at UAB. They keep the organization functioning in spite of Upper-level management.
cons: On one can make a decision. No leadership at the top, no guidance is given, so no one wants to make a decision. There seem to be a lot of little power struggles within small domains of influence. Crisis management. If you make the wrong person mad or expose issues (security) that make someone else look bad you will be the one that gets fired.

pros:
Culture of family 
Great Benefits 
Paid Maternity/Paternity leave
Flexibility in schedule 
Tuition reimbursement for healthcare related majors
Ease of transferring to other areas within the system
cons:
Poor communication from administration all the way to direct supervisors
Administration lacks the understanding of frontline workers
Lack of appreciation and education of non-nursing positions
Lack of advancement in non-nursing positions
No competitive pay
Poor work life balance
Administration fosters a culture of micromanagement 
Constant turnover in administration and frontline workers 
Constant change in workflow

job_title: Call Center Representative in Avondale, AL
pros: They go and above to make sure you’re trained properly or at least try to make it seem that way...
cons: I feel like you don’t ever know if you’re in the wrong or not, they’ll talk amongst other supervisors. Assure you you’re good when I feel like they try “ sugar coating” without coming out saying you’re doing a bad job.

pros: Hours are great. Benefits are okay. Some days management can be okay, it just depends on who you have to deal with.
cons: The pay structure could be updated a lot!!!!!!!! Employees who have been there for years are barely surviving while people who just graduated from CMA training are making $15 an hour. That's an insult and a slao in the face to someone who has been with the company for years who is not even making $11 an hour.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Birmingham, AL
pros: Beautiful building. Patients are usually wonderful. Love the girls I work with.
cons: ALWAYS understaffed. Usually by 3-4 nurses daily. Pay is low. Amount of work expected to do in 12 hours is impossible. On a good day it is fine. But there is no help or support when you do the job of two nurses almost daily.

pros: I loved working at UAB. Coworkers seemed to genuinely care about the patients and I felt proud to work with such talented people.  They also offered benefits like flexible off time, in house health insurance, and membership in a conveniently located health club (for $30 a month)
cons: Not much room for career advancement and the pay wasn't that great.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Birmingham, AL
pros: Good pay, great benefits, wonderful learning new things, wonderful docs. Docs are wonderful about teaching staff and explaining procedures. Always something new to learn.
cons: Too many chiefs, everybody  is is pitted against each other.Rules are changed far to often. My last supervisor talked about her staff with other members of her staff.  Very bad attitude from supervisors. Had favorites.

pros: Skilled and committed co-workers; diverse patient population;
cons:
Management systematically gets rid of employees with seniority so they can hire new workers for less pay.
Management in some areas does not hire African-American or Latino professional clinicians (e.g., Allied Health professionals with 4+ year degrees).
The "leadership" is all about maximizing profits, even if it negatively affects the quality of care.
Morale is very poor due to understaffing.

pros:
Great environment to work if you are interested.
Great people.
Positive vibes very friendly environment on both floors at all times.
cons:
The jobs duties of a PCA as a female are stressful on the body.
Only men work as PCA's.
A lot of pushing and pulling of patients and surgical equipment throughout the day.
As a female I wouldn't recommend this position especially if you are seeking something a lot less stressful on your body.

pros: I got a chance to work in a great establishment
cons: Worked in evs had a hard time moving out of evs to pct. They saw how I worked and I've talked to several charge nurses one loved the way o worked and said she would vouch for my work ethics but they still wouldn't hire me

pros: Strong academic crews, nice people! I am in the grad school under UAB Medicine. The labs have state of the art facilities. They have strong bio-medical background. Pay is good, especially when the living standard is lower here.
cons: Southern small/midtown feeling; if you are from a big city in the north, it might be a little different. People are a little lay back (It is in the south, haha).

review_title: Very easy job to obtain once interviewed
job_title: PATIENT ENCOUNTER SPECIALIST in Birmingham, AL
pros: There are very great benefits working at UAB medicine. It also offers free tuition for attending UAB in undergraduate and graduate studies
cons: Depending on the position, you may end up with a very non competitive salary l. Very hard to move up. UAB requires you to wait a year before transferring

job_title: Senior Certified Pharmacy Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Good insurance, lots of OT opportunities
cons: Mgmt doesn’t communicate well or listen to the staff, they make promises they can’t keep (i.e working every 3rd weekend instead of every other was promised for 1.5yrs and never happened); no advancement opportunities, mgmt plays favorites

pros: Challenging work in a fast paced, comfortable environment.  Good pay and benefits and opportunity to move up or to other departments.
cons: Limited training in some areas. Being downtown. Parking can be an issue.  Highly driven in most jobs with unrealistic expectations.

review_title: Good employer, but their budget cuts have left employees feeling neglected: no bonus, no raise, no shift diff, etc.
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Birmingham, AL
pros: Steady employment, participating in cutting-edge research, high tech equipment, high standard of practice and care
cons: Attendance policy only allows 3 calls-ins per year, which I feel is very unrealistic

pros: Depending on your job it might be easy to work from home, and my research department was not into micromanaging.
cons: The job was really stressful (clinical trials research), lots of taking work home with you for not enough pay in my opinion and hourly at that so you're working a lot more hours then you are allowed to log and get paid for.

pros: As a new grad, getting a job at UAB is kind of intimidating but I have had the best experience so far and learned so much.
cons: Pay could be a little higher but Alabama is one of the worst states to work as a nurse in regards to pay so I don't think that's UABs fault.

review_title: Overall it was good, however, there are too many chiefs and not enough Indians to work efficiently in some areas.
pros: Great benefits and flexible work hours.
cons: As I said, too many executive opinions on how things should be done, and none of them agree.

pros: Great place to work, benefits are good and there is room for growth. Corteous and helpfull staff. Enjoyable experience. Love the place
cons: Low pay for the amount of work done. Recruitment takes a long time as one tends to get frustrated while waiting. Good thing is at least they send an email notifying you that the position has been filled

pros: Free tuition for BSN or MSN
cons: No flexibility in schedule especially holidays. Only allowed vacation request for one weekend off per YEAR. No autonomy for nurses. Management only talks to staff if there is a problem. Not hello, good morning, nothing. Street parking or pay to park and ride a bus

review_title: Great Place to Make Career.....if you can handle the politics
job_title: Research Nurse Coordinator in Birmingham, AL
pros: Tons of growth opportunities for RN's.  Great scheduling options.  Pay is competitive for the market.
cons: Parking is expensive and the parking staff is rude and condescending when called for questions.   Alot of ancillary staff, that are not working with patients, are difficult to work with.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Great benefits and educational assistance.  Many opportunities to learn. Some good co-workers.
cons: Management on my unit did not foster unity among employees, instead, a culture of bias, mistrust, and bullying was created.  Communication is not so great.

review_title: Overall Great Organization to Work For
pros: Ahead of other hospitals with best practices and technology. Many educational opportunities all year round. Room to grow and advance. More resources than other facilities. Great CEO.
cons: Not many cons. Sometimes hard to keep up with the many changes. Also, parking cost is high.

pros: Good values and work life balance. Doing work that matters
cons: Getting your voice heard when their are so many leaders, top heavy org

pros: Free tuition at UAB campus. That's all I can think of. Except my coworkers are some of the hardest working and most pleasant people I have ever worked with. Management excluded.

Management has declared war on employees. And HR is not your friend.
Sick policy is a joke. Don't come here unless you're sure you will never get sick.

review_title: Lots of politics. Not very much room for growth or promotion.

cons: Pay is low. Too much office politics. Benefits are not great.

pros: Brilliant minds and some truly wonderful people work at UAB. People are kind and friendly and understanding. My colleagues are some of my best friends and I respect there faculty so much.
cons: You do work your butt off but it’s worth it!

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Team work.  Family.  I worked nearly my entire 20 years in either the Emergency Department or PACU or Pre-Op.  Loved the team work in those areas.
cons: No cons.  There. Is that five words?

pros:
The pay was sufficient for my position. 
Uab has a great reputation

pros: Incredible benefits and opportunities to gain training and expertise in all areas.

pros: They have good benefits if you want to go back to school

pros: Good networking possibilities. UAB is a good place to work for, and management is not too demanding. You can learn to expect things in a very systematic way.

pros: Benefits, southern hospitality, opportunities for growth
